API Documentation¶

class azner.data.data.CharSpan(*, start: int, end: int)¶

A concept similar to a Spacy Span, except is offset based rather than token based

class azner.data.data.Entity(*, namespace: str, match: str, entity_class: str, start: int, end: int, hash_val: str = None, metadata: azner.data.data.EntityMetadata = None)¶

Generic data class representing a unique entity in a string

as_brat()¶
Returns

self as the third party biomedical nlp Brat format, (see docs on Brat)

exact_overlap(other, also_same_class: bool = False)¶

compare one entity to other

Parameters

  • other – query Entity

  • also_same_class – if True, will return true if entity_class matches

overlapped(other) → bool¶

Test for distinct offsets

Parameters

other – query Entity

Returns

True if the offsets are completely distinct, False otherwise

class azner.data.data.NerProcessedSection(*, all_frame_offsets: List[Tuple[int, int]] = None, all_frame_word_ids: List[Optional[int]] = None, all_frame_labels: List[int] = None, all_frame_confidences: List[float] = None)¶

long Sections may need to be split into multiple frames when processing with a transformer. This class is a convenient container to reassemble the frames into a coherent object, post transformer

to_tokenized_words(id2label: Dict[int, str]) → List[azner.data.data.TokenizedWord]¶

return a List[TokenizedWord]

Parameters

id2label – Dict mapping labels to strings

Returns

class azner.data.data.TokenizedWord(*, word_labels: List[int] = None, word_labels_strings: List[str] = None, word_confidences: List[float] = None, word_offsets: List[Tuple[int, int]] = None, bio_labels: List[str] = None, class_labels: List[str] = None, modified_post_inference: bool = False)¶

A convenient container for a word, which may be split into multiple tokens by e.g. WordPiece tokenisation

parse_labels_to_bio_and_class()¶

since the BIO schema actually encodes two pieces of info, it’s often useful to handle them separately. This method parses the BIO labels in self.word_labels_strings and add the fields bio_labels and class labels :return:

class azner.data.pytorch.HFDataset(encodings: transformers.tokenization_utils_base.BatchEncoding)¶
reinforce_type(expected_type)¶

Reinforce the type for DataPipe instance. And the ‘expected_type’ is required to be a subtype of the original type hint to restrict the type requirement of DataPipe instance.

class azner.modelling.hf_lightning_wrappers.PLAutoModel(model: transformers.models.auto.modeling_auto.AutoModel, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any)¶
predict_step(batch: Any, batch_idx: int, dataloader_idx: Optional[int] = None) → Any¶

Step function called during predict(). By default, it calls forward(). Override to add any processing logic.

The predict_step() is used to scale inference on multi-devices.

To prevent an OOM error, it is possible to use BasePredictionWriter callback to write the predictions to disk or database after each batch or on epoch end.

The BasePredictionWriter should be used while using a spawn based accelerator. This happens for Trainer(accelerator="ddp_spawn") or training on 8 TPU cores with Trainer(tpu_cores=8) as predictions won’t be returned.

Example

class MyModel(LightningModule):

    def predicts_step(self, batch, batch_idx, dataloader_idx):
        return self(batch)

dm = ...
model = MyModel()
trainer = Trainer(gpus=2)
predictions = trainer.predict(model, dm)
Args:

batch: Current batch batch_idx: Index of current batch dataloader_idx: Index of the current dataloader

Return:

Predicted output

class azner.modelling.hf_lightning_wrappers.PLAutoModelForTokenClassification(model: transformers.models.auto.modeling_auto.AutoModelForTokenClassification, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any)¶
predict_step(batch: Any, batch_idx: int, dataloader_idx: Optional[int] = None) → Any¶

Step function called during predict(). By default, it calls forward(). Override to add any processing logic.

The predict_step() is used to scale inference on multi-devices.

To prevent an OOM error, it is possible to use BasePredictionWriter callback to write the predictions to disk or database after each batch or on epoch end.

The BasePredictionWriter should be used while using a spawn based accelerator. This happens for Trainer(accelerator="ddp_spawn") or training on 8 TPU cores with Trainer(tpu_cores=8) as predictions won’t be returned.

Example

class MyModel(LightningModule):

    def predicts_step(self, batch, batch_idx, dataloader_idx):
        return self(batch)

dm = ...
model = MyModel()
trainer = Trainer(gpus=2)
predictions = trainer.predict(model, dm)
Args:

batch: Current batch batch_idx: Index of current batch dataloader_idx: Index of the current dataloader

Return:

Predicted output

class azner.steps.linking.link_ensembling.MappingPostProcessing(entity: azner.data.data.Entity, linker_score_thresholds: Dict[str, float])¶

Ensemble and resolve mapping information for an entity, according to a custom algorithm: 1) exact string match hit in ontology -> High confidence 2) scores above threshold for a single linker -> Medium-high confidence 3) different linkers suggest same ontology id -> Medium-high confidence 4) matched text is contained in, or contains mapping default label or synonym -> Medium confidence 5) best score overall, across all linkers -> Low confidence

exact_hits() → List[azner.data.data.Mapping]¶

returns any perfect mappings - i.e. mappings where the match is the same as the default label, synonym, or linker score is 100.0 (depends on linkers correctly normalising scores between 0-100). High confidence :return:

filter_scores() → List[azner.data.data.Mapping]¶

do any of the mappings return a score above a threshold for a linker, to suggest a good mapping? :return:

query_contained_in_hits() → List[azner.data.data.Mapping]¶

is the match substring in any of the mappings, or vice versa? Medium confidence. Note, we only check matches of 5 chars or more, otherwise will be noisy :return:

similarly_ranked() → List[azner.data.data.Mapping]¶

compare the results of all mapping id’s between linkers via set.intersection. Return any that all linkers agree on, sorted by score :return:

class azner.utils.caching.EntityLinkingLookupCache(lookup_cache_size: int = 5000)¶

A simple wrapper around LFUCache to reduce calls to expensive processes (e.g. bert)

check_lookup_cache(entities: List[azner.data.data.Entity]) → List[azner.data.data.Entity]¶

checks the cache for mappings. If relevant mappings are found for an entity, update it’s mappings accordingly. If not return as a list of cache misses (e.g. for further processing)

Parameters

entities –

Returns
